curam.util.common.path
Interface Step

public interface Step

A step is a component of a Path. Each step in the path refines the selection made by the preceding steps. A step has a selector and optional predicates. The selector identifies what is to be selected by the step and the predicates may refine what is selected by imposing certain conditions. The predicates are delimited by surrounding them with square brackets and follow the selector. For example, "/data/values[1]" is a path with two steps: the first has a selector "data", the second has a selector "values" and a predicate "1", that refines the selection to the first value. Predicates created from parsing path strings will be string objects, but when a predicate is added to an existing step, it may be another type of object. This makes it more efficient to use predicates for numeric indexes.

Method Detail

getSelector

java.lang.String getSelector()
Gets the selector part of this step.

Returns:
The step selector.

getPredicate

java.lang.Object getPredicate(int predicateIndex)
Gets the predicate at the given index. The first predicate has index zero. The predicate is the contents of what appears in the square brackets in the string representation of the step, it does not include these brackets. If the brackets contained nothing, then the predicate will be an empty string (not null). Predicates set using the Path.applyIndex(int, int, boolean) method can be other types of objects to enable efficient handling of numeric indexes.

Parameters:
predicateIndex - The index of the predicate to get.
Returns:
The required predicate.
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index does not correspond to a predicate of the step.

applyIndex

Step applyIndex(int indexValue)
Creates a new step that replaces the first empty predicate with a predicate whose value is the given index. If there is no empty predicate, no change will be made and this step will be returned. The index predicate is stored as a java.lang.Integer object. For example, applying the index value one to the step "a[]" results in "a[1]", but "a" would remain unchanged.

Parameters:
indexValue - The value of the index to apply to the step.
Returns:
A new step with the required index predicate, or this step if no empty predicate was found.

applyIndex

Step applyIndex(java.lang.Object indexValue)
Creates a new step that replaces the first empty predicate with a predicate whose value is the given index. This is the same as Step.applyIndex(int), but the predicate will be the given object, not an integer. The object must not be modified after it has been applied as a predicate value. If the index value object is null, then a new step is not created and this step is returned unchanged.

Parameters:
indexValue - The value of the index to apply to the step.
Returns:
A new step with the required index predicate, or this step if no empty predicate was found.

size

int size()
Gets the number of predicates in this step.

Returns:
The number of predicates.

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object object)
Determines if this step is equal to another step. Steps are equal if they are not null, are both steps (and not some other type), they have the same number of predicates, their selectors are equal and their corresponding predicates are equal.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
object - The step (or other object) to be tested for equality with this step.
Returns:
true if this step is equal to the given step, false otherwise.

toString

java.lang.String toString()
Gets the string representation of this step and its predicates.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
The step and predicates as a string.
